general: This law sets up an organization called the "Law Commission" to review and improve the laws of England and Wales. The commission will look at existing laws, suggest changes or updates where necessary, and provide recommendations for new laws. The goal is to make sure the legal system is fair, efficient, and effective in serving the public.

series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Law Commission Act 2009 requires the Lord Chancellor to prepare an annual report on the implementation of Law Commission proposals.
* Simplified point 2: The report must cover the proposals implemented during the year, as well as any plans for dealing with unimplemented proposals and the reasons for any decisions not to implement them.
* Simplified point 3: The report must also cover any decisions not to implement proposals made before the first reporting year.
* Simplified point 4: The Law Commission and the Lord Chancellor may agree on a protocol regarding the Law Commission's work, which must be laid before Parliament.
* Simplified point 5: The Act comes into force at the end of two months after it is passed.

summary: The Law Commission Act 2009 ensures that the government keeps track of their progress in implementing changes to laws proposed by the Law Commission. This includes reporting each year on which proposals have been implemented, why some proposals were not implemented, and any future plans for dealing with unimplemented proposals. Additionally, the government and the Law Commission can create a plan for how they will work together, which must be shared with Parliament. Overall, this law helps keep the legal system up-to-date and effective.
single:
* The Law Commission Act 2009 requires the Lord Chancellor to prepare an annual report on the implementation of Law Commission proposals.
* The report must include information on proposals implemented, proposals not implemented, and any decisions not to implement proposals.
* The Law Commission Act 2009 also requires the Lord Chancellor and the Law Commission to agree on a protocol about the Law Commission's work, which may include provision about principles and methods to be applied in deciding the work to be carried out by the Law Commission and in the carrying out of that work.
* The protocol must be reviewed from time to time and laid before Parliament.
* The Law Commission Act 2009 comes into force at the end of the period of 2 months beginning with the day on which it is passed.
* The Law Commission Act 2009 may be cited as the Law Commission Act 2009.
